record.source: 2025 IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition (APEC), Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition (APEC), 2025 IEEE
record.title: Novel Approach of Determining and Predicting SiC MOSFETâ€™s On Resistance From Device Case Temperature Using Machine Learning
record.subjects: Components, Circuits, Devices and Systems ; Power, Energy and Industry Applications ; Temperature measurement ; MOSFET ; Power measurement ; Silicon carbide ; Machine learning ; Predictive models ; Prediction algorithms ; Power electronics ; Reliability ; Monitoring ; Machine Learning ; SiC MOSFET ; EV Charging ; Accelerated Lifetime Test ; Health Monitoring ; Remaining Useful Life
record.abstract: Silicon-carbide (SiC) MOSFET devices are increasing in popularity in high-power converter applications. Device on-resistance (R dson ) is an important indicator for SiC MOSFET health status. Increments in R dson over device lifetime indicate imminent device failure and result in decreased system efficiency. Direct and accurate measurement of SiC MOSFET device R dson in high-power applications is difficult. Another approach is to estimate/predict the device R dson from other, more easily measurable quantities, however, little work has been done on this approach in the literature. This leaves a significant technical gap in measuring/predicting device R dson and slows down the device health status monitoring and power converter reliability research. To address the technical gaps, this work proposes a novel approach to predicting device R dson from thermal cycle count and instantaneous temperature using machine learning regression models. The actual hardware data collected from accelerated lifetime tests of high-power SiC MOSFETs are used to train, test, and validate the proposed machine-learning regression models. The developed models, coupled with cycle counting algorithms, and device case thermal measurements, provide accurate live estimates of R dson and can be used to predict changes in R dson over expected mission profiles during power converter design.
record.contributors: Bradford, Paul ; Deppe, Conner ; Wang, Hongjie
